articles.title: Royal Navy returns to wind power with trial of robotic sailboats
articles.summary: A fleet of wind-propelled robot boats could act as a sensor network covering a wide area and relay acoustic signals to a submarine
articles.content:
A fleet of wind-propelled robot boats could act as a sensor network covering a wide area and relay acoustic signals to a submarine

Oshen’s robotic sailboats are powered by the wind and the sun Oshen

The UK’s Royal Navy may return to the age of sail, with a new demonstration involving a flotilla of small, wind-propelled robot boats.

Made by Oshen in Plymouth, UK, the vessels, known as C-Stars, are just 1.2 metres long and weigh around 40 kilos. Solar panels power navigation, communications and sensors, while a sail provides propulsion. Deployed as a constellation, the small vessels act as a wide-area sensor network.

“The simplest way of describing C-Stars is as self-deploying, station-keeping ocean buoys,” says Oshen CEO Anahita Laverack.

The boats can sail at about 2 knots, covering around 50 miles per day, or use the wind to remain in place rather than drifting. They don’t need to be fast. “Speed is not important when you are a CCTV network,” says Laverack. “The idea is to position sensors everywhere you need them.”

In the trial announced this month, a larger robotic vessel will transport three C-Stars and drop them off in the target area. The C-Stars will then relay acoustic signals from an uncrewed submarine. Many more would be deployed in a live operation.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Daily The latest on what’s new in science and why it matters each day. Sign up to newsletter

“If you only have one, then the adversary can tell the general area of the submarine it is communicating with. If you have a hundred, the submarine could be anywhere, under any of them,” says Laverick.

The uncrewed boats can stay at sea for six months or more and survive the worst sea states. Last year, C-Stars became the first uncrewed vessels to provide live data from inside a category 5 storm, as part of a research project involving the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

If the navy demonstration is successful, robot sailboats could take on a variety of roles. In addition to communication with submarines and seabed sensors, they could form picket lines to detect ships, incoming missiles, or drones trying to sneak under radar.

C-Stars also seem ideal for submarine detection as an alternative to disposable sonar-equipped buoys, which only last a few hours. They can use their hydrophones to listen for subs or pick up reflected sonar pings from an external source such as a warship. In this scenario, the ship’s sonar effectively lights up an area, so that the C-Stars can see anything near them.

Blair Thornton at the University of Southampton, UK, says solar- and wind-powered uncrewed vessels have gradually become accepted over the last decade, and around 100 of various types are in service. He says autonomy will be essential with a fleet of them.

“It isn’t only the platform costs, but it is how much oversight they need for their operations,” says Thornton. “The combination of long endurance, robust operations with minimal need for human interaction can be a major advantage and allow large fleets of autonomous systems to operate.”

The latest demonstration aims to show C-Stars can easily integrate with existing navy systems. Oshen could deliver 1000 boats with a nine-month lead time if the navy decides to place an order.

“The next level will involve software refinements so we can see more detail and achieve better coverage of a wider area with fewer C-Stars,” says Laverack.

This represents a meaningful advancement in sustainable maritime technology with applications in defense and ocean observation, offering measurable benefits such as extended operational duration, reduced environmental footprint, and enhanced situational awareness. The article provides sufficient detail about the technology, its capabilities, and potential uses, making it a substantive and inspiring story of technological progress.
articles.personality_title: Royal Navy tests wind-powered robot sailboats to boost underwater sensing
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The UK Royal Navy is exploring new ways to monitor the ocean using small robotic boats powered by wind and solar energy. These boats, called C-Stars, are designed to stay at sea for long periods without needing fuel.

**What happened** – A trial began where a larger vessel released three C-Star robotic sailboats into the sea. These 1.2-meter-long boats use sails to move and solar panels to power their sensors and communications. Their job is to relay sounds from an uncrewed submarine, acting like a network of floating listening posts.

**Impact** – This approach allows the Navy to cover a large area quietly and for months at a time. Unlike traditional sonar buoys that only last a few hours, these robotic boats can survive storms and stay active for six months or more. Having many boats spread out makes it harder for others to find the submarine, improving security and surveillance.

**What's next step** – If the trial works well, the Navy could order up to 1,000 of these boats. Future improvements will focus on better software to cover wider areas with fewer boats. These boats might also help detect ships, missiles, or drones, expanding their role beyond submarine tracking.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The Royal Navy is testing wind- and solar-powered robotic sailboats to create a durable, quiet sensor network that improves underwater monitoring over long periods.

articles.personality_title_es: La Marina Real prueba veleros robotizados con energía eólica para mejorar la detección submarina
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Marina Real del Reino Unido está explorando nuevas formas de vigilar el océano usando pequeños barcos robotizados impulsados por viento y energía solar. Estos barcos, llamados C-Stars, están diseñados para permanecer mucho tiempo en el mar sin necesidad de combustible.

**Qué pasó** – Comenzó una prueba donde un barco más grande lanzó tres veleros robotizados C-Star al mar. Estos barcos de 1,2 metros usan velas para moverse y paneles solares para alimentar sus sensores y comunicaciones. Su tarea es transmitir sonidos de un submarino no tripulado, formando una red flotante de escucha.

**Impacto** – Este método permite a la Marina cubrir una gran área de forma silenciosa y durante meses. A diferencia de las boyas sonar tradicionales que duran pocas horas, estos barcos pueden soportar tormentas y estar activos más de seis meses. Tener muchos barcos dispersos dificulta encontrar el submarino, mejorando la seguridad.

**Próximo paso** – Si la prueba tiene éxito, la Marina podría ordenar hasta 1,000 de estos barcos. Las mejoras futuras se centrarán en mejor software para cubrir áreas más amplias con menos barcos. Estos veleros también podrían ayudar a detectar barcos, misiles o drones, ampliando su función.

**Resumen en una frase** – La Marina Real prueba veleros robotizados con energía eólica y solar para crear una red de sensores duradera y silenciosa que mejora la vigilancia submarina a largo plazo.

articles.title: AI help in grant proposals tied to higher funding odds at NIH
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 12 February 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00369-3But funding proposals to US agencies also tend to be more similar to previously funded projects if they are written or edited with the help of a chatbot.
articles.content:
Many funding proposals submitted to the US National Institutes of Health and National Science Foundation are written with the assistance of artificial-intelligence programs.Credit: Getty

Scientists are increasingly turning to artificial-intelligence systems for help drafting the grant proposals that fund their careers, but preliminary data1 indicate that these tools might be pulling the focus of research towards safe, less-innovative ideas.

These data provide evidence that AI-assisted proposals submitted to the US National Institutes of Health (NIH) are consistently less distinct from previous research than ones written without the use of AI — and are also slightly more likely to be funded.

These results indicate that, if the trend continues, “we could be on a path towards homogeneity”, says Misha Teplitskiy, a science, technology and policy researcher at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. “This paper provides some suggestive evidence of that happening.”

The analysis, which has not yet been peer reviewed, was posted on the preprint server arXiv on 21 January.

Artificial editors

Since large language models (LLMs) became mainstream in 2023, most scientists have tried using AI tools to assist them with researching their ideas and writing and editing their manuscripts, according to a 2024 survey2. Dashun Wang and Yifan Qian, computational social scientists at Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois, were curious whether this rapid and widespread adoption of AI tools has changed the type of science that is funded.

AI is transforming peer review — and many scientists are worried

Typically, grant applications, particularly those that are unsuccessful, are not easily accessible, making it difficult to answer this question. But Wang and Qian gained access to and analysed thousands of grant proposals that were submitted to the US National Science Foundation (NSF) and the NIH by researchers at two large US universities between 2021 and 2025. They also collected data from publicly available grant abstracts in a database of federally funded grants.

To spot AI-tool use, the researchers took thousands of these public abstracts from 2021 — written before the rise of OpenAI’s ChatGPT chatbot — and asked an AI model to rewrite them. By comparing the human and AI versions of the same text, the team learnt the telltale signs that separate human writing from machine-generated text. They then used this knowledge to analyse grant applications at the two universities and give each one a score that was representative of how much of the writing contained AI-associated patterns. A higher score meant that a larger portion of the proposal showed signs of being drafted or edited by AI tools.

AI avoidance

The use of AI for writing grant proposals spiked in early 2023, following the public release of ChatGPT, the researchers found. But it wasn’t adopted by everyone: the study revealed that there was a group of scientists who mostly avoided AI when preparing their proposals. Those who did use AI tools generated roughly 10–15% of their text with them.

The outcomes for AI-assisted proposals differed by funding agency. At the NIH, high AI involvement was linked to a 4% jump in the likelihood of a successful application, compared with low AI involvement. It was also associated with a 5% increase in the number of papers published about the funded work, compared with applications with low levels of AI involvement. This jump in papers was mostly made up of articles that were not highly cited. At the NSF, however, the authors detected no benefit to using AI tools.

“This link between LLM use and NIH award rates is striking and substantial,” Teplitskiy says.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant real-world impact where AI assistance in writing NIH grant proposals is linked to higher funding success, potentially improving research productivity and funding efficiency. The study covers a broad scope affecting many scientists and the research community, providing detailed analysis and implications of AI use in grant writing. However, it also raises concerns about research homogeneity, which tempers the overall positivity.
articles.personality_title: AI helps scientists win more NIH research grants but may limit new ideas
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists need funding to carry out their research, often applying to agencies like the US National Institutes of Health (NIH) and National Science Foundation (NSF). Writing these grant proposals is a big task, and many researchers have started using artificial intelligence (AI) tools to help draft and edit their applications since 2023.

**What happened** – A recent study analyzed thousands of grant proposals submitted between 2021 and 2025. Researchers found that proposals written with AI help were about 4% more likely to get funded by the NIH compared to those written without AI. These AI-assisted proposals also led to slightly more published papers about the funded work. However, proposals using AI tended to be more similar to past projects, suggesting less originality. At the NSF, no clear benefit from AI use was found.

**Impact** – This study shows that AI tools can improve scientists’ chances of getting NIH funding and increase research output, which may help scientists focus more on their work than writing. But the similarity of AI-written proposals to previous projects raises a concern: research might become less creative and more repetitive over time if AI tools guide too much of the writing.

**What's next step** – Researchers will likely keep studying how AI affects the ideas and quality of funded science. Funding agencies might consider how to encourage innovation while using AI assistance. Scientists may also explore ways to use AI without losing originality in their proposals.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Using AI tools can help scientists win more NIH grants but may also make research projects less unique over time.
articles.personality_title_fr: L’IA aide les scientifiques à obtenir plus de subventions NIH mais pourrait limiter l’innovation
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques ont besoin de financements pour leurs recherches, souvent demandés auprès d’agences comme les National Institutes of Health (NIH) et la National Science Foundation (NSF) aux États-Unis. Rédiger ces demandes de subvention est un travail important, et depuis 2023, beaucoup utilisent des outils d’intelligence artificielle (IA) pour les aider.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une étude récente a analysé des milliers de propositions de subvention soumises entre 2021 et 2025. Les chercheurs ont découvert que les propositions aidées par l’IA avaient environ 4 % de chances en plus d’être financées par le NIH comparé aux propositions sans IA. Ces propositions ont aussi conduit à un peu plus de publications sur les travaux financés. Cependant, les propositions écrites avec l’IA étaient souvent plus proches des projets déjà financés, ce qui suggère moins d’originalité. À la NSF, aucun bénéfice clair lié à l’IA n’a été observé.

**Impact** – Cette étude montre que les outils d’IA peuvent améliorer les chances des scientifiques d’obtenir des financements NIH et augmenter la production scientifique, ce qui peut leur permettre de se concentrer davantage sur leur recherche. Mais la ressemblance des propositions écrites par l’IA avec des projets déjà existants pose un risque : la recherche pourrait devenir moins créative et plus répétitive.

**Prochaines étapes** – Les chercheurs continueront à étudier l’impact de l’IA sur la qualité et la créativité des projets financés. Les agences de financement pourraient chercher à encourager l’innovation tout en utilisant l’IA. Les scientifiques chercheront aussi des moyens d’utiliser l’IA sans perdre en originalité.

**Une phrase clé** – L’utilisation de l’IA aide à obtenir plus de subventions NIH, mais pourrait rendre les projets de recherche moins uniques avec le temps.
articles.personality_title_es: La IA ayuda a científicos a obtener más subvenciones del NIH pero podría limitar nuevas ideas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos necesitan financiamiento para sus investigaciones, que suelen solicitar a agencias como el Instituto Nacional de Salud (NIH) y la Fundación Nacional de Ciencia (NSF) de Estados Unidos. Escribir estas propuestas es una tarea difícil, y desde 2023 muchos investigadores usan herramientas de inteligencia artificial (IA) para ayudar a redactarlas.

**Qué pasó** – Un estudio reciente analizó miles de propuestas enviadas entre 2021 y 2025. Los investigadores encontraron que las propuestas hechas con ayuda de IA tenían un 4 % más de probabilidades de ser financiadas por el NIH en comparación con las hechas sin IA. Estas propuestas también produjeron un poco más de artículos publicados sobre el trabajo financiado. Sin embargo, las propuestas con IA tendían a ser más parecidas a proyectos anteriores, lo que sugiere menos originalidad. En la NSF no se encontró un beneficio claro por usar IA.

**Impacto** – Este estudio muestra que las herramientas de IA pueden mejorar las posibilidades de los científicos para conseguir fondos del NIH y aumentar la producción científica, lo que podría ayudarles a concentrarse más en su investigación. Pero la similitud de las propuestas con IA a proyectos anteriores plantea la preocupación de que la investigación pueda volverse menos creativa y más repetitiva.

**Próximo paso** – Es probable que los investigadores sigan estudiando cómo la IA afecta las ideas y la calidad de la ciencia financiada. Las agencias de financiamiento podrían buscar maneras de fomentar la innovación mientras usan la IA. Los científicos también explorarán cómo usar la IA sin perder originalidad.

**Una frase clave** – Usar herramientas de IA puede ayudar a los científicos a obtener más subvenciones del NIH, pero también podría hacer que los proyectos de investigación sean menos únicos con el tiempo.
